citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.
citations.narrative:
Records show a female nonhuman primate (NHP), detected to have a breast lump, was not euthanized within the
timeframe recommended by the attending veterinarian (AV). The AV advised the animal staff member via email of the
decision to euthanize the NHP that day, a Friday, but was not done by the animal staff member until the following
Monday. Records state the staff member did not see the email in time and delayed the procedure. The facility has taken
immediate corrective action to prevent reoccurrence. Failure to have a mechanism of direct and timely communication
between the attending veterinarian and animal staff concerning animal health can result in unnecessary discomfort to the
animals. A system must be in place to ensure a mechanism of direct and frequent communication is in place so that
timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed between the
attending veterinarian and animal staff members.
To be corrected from this day forward March 28, 2024

The majority of hard rubber or plastic enrichment items provided to the nonhuman primates were worn to the point that
the items could no longer be properly sanitized and/or they posed a danger to the animals if the worn portions of the items
were consumed. The facility’s Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for the Enrichment of Non-Human Primates states
that the “Toys that appear as though they may pose a danger to the animal will be promptly removed”, Including “toys that
appear worn to the point that they cannot be properly sanitized.” Enrichment items that have excessive wear cannot be
effectively cleaned or sanitized. Excessively worn or damaged items could potentially be ingested requiring veterinary
intervention for removal. All surfaces in contact with nonhuman primates to be readily cleaned and sanitized or replaced
when worn or soiled.
To be corrected by April 12, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Geoffrey Olsen, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
William Campbell, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
